awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research:  Information integration by gene regulatory networks controlling bacterial cell fate decisions
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacterial biofilms, which are surface associated aggregates of cells, are highly resistant to toxic chemicals such as chlorine and to many antibiotics that are used to treat human infections.  This project aims to understand how cells decide to form a biofilm by analyzing a gene regulatory network that is crucial for the decision-making process. The mechanisms underlying these decision-making processes are not fully understood, even for the best-studied gene regulatory networks. Using the biofilm-forming bacterium Bacillus subtilis as a model, this research will define general principles underlying decision making by regulatory networks. B. subtilis is closely related to and shares many regulatory networks with medically important pathogenic bacteria, including Clostridium sp., B. cereus, and B. anthracis. Hence, this work may serve as a model for understanding how such bacteria decide to initiate biofilm formation.  This project will provide students with interdisciplinary training in microbiology and mathematical modeling.  A special emphasis will be placed on engaging underrepresented students from the University of Houston, which has been designated as a Hispanic-Serving Institution.  

This proposal aims to obtain a systems-level understanding of how B. subtilis cells sense starvation and make the decision to initiate either a unicellular (sporulation) or a multicellular (biofilm) differentiation program for survival. The proposal will test whether gene-regulatory networks are able to assess nutrient availability by sensing the cell growth rate. Further, it will investigate how different dynamics (i.e. modulation of activity in time) of a single master transcriptional regulator can direct cells to alternative cell fates. These questions will be addressed with a synergistic combination of systems and synthetic biology tools, including synthetic network perturbations and rewiring, single-cell imaging, statistical data analysis, and mathematical modeling. Thus, this project will illustrate various fundamental concepts of complex (but not too complex) living systems. The project will also provide abundant interdisciplinary training opportunities for the participating students and postdocs working together on experiments and/or mathematical modeling.

por.por_cntn:
Cell-fate decision is a fundamental mechanism underlying complex morphogenesis not only in multicellular organisms but also bacterial communities. Generally, multiple cell fate decisions are controlled by a single master regulator, which is activated in response to different environmental stimuli. However, the mechanisms underlying the ability of these regulators to control multiple outcomes in response to environmental cues are not understood in many systems. Using Bacillus subtilis as a simple unicellular model system, we employ a combination of mathematical modeling and empirical study to explain the mechanisms of cell-fate decision to biofilm formation and spore formation (sporulation) for cell survival.

(1) Kinases normally act as a source of a phosphate group to phosphorylate downstream master regulators to be activates as a transcription regulator. We show that KinC, one of the multiple kinases, acts as a sink to compete with KinA, the major kinase to phosphorylate Spo0A master regulator of biofilm formation and sporulation. As a result of bifurcated regulation of two kinases, Spo0A activity is accurately controlled in response to nutrient starvation to determine whether cells enter biofilm formation or sporulation.

(2) Generally, kinases receive signals (ligands) and start transduction in response to environmental changes to contribute to cell survival and growth. We show that cells increase kinase activities when cells slow down their growth rates under starvation conditions. As a result of the increase in kinase activity, high Spo0A activity is achieved via phosphorelay signal transduction, leading to spore formation. These design features enable cells to robustly make their cell fate decision whether to grow or enter spore formation for survival without sensing any specific signals or metabolites in the environment by kinases. Our finding is in contrast to the current consensus mechanism in which kinases sense as-yet-unidentified starvation signals or metabolites in the environment to activate them.

(3) Biofilm formation occurs at relatively early phases of starvation, while sporulation starts at later stages with prolonged starvation. We show the mechanisms of how the same regulator Spo0A controls these two cell fates, biofilm formation and sporulation differently. Data indicate that the decrease in the cellular growth rate affects matrix production via an additional incoherent feed-forward network composed of SinI-SinR-SlrR proteins. Kinases are activated with slowing down cell growth to increase in Spo0A activity but genes involved in biofilm formation are repressed by the SinI-SinR-SlrR network, while genes involved in sporulation are under the direct control of Spo0A without the SinI-SinR-SlrR network control. These design features enable cells to robustly make their cell fate decisions.

(4) The Spo0A transcription factor activated by phosphorylation (Spo0A~P) differentially controls a set of genes involved in biofilm formation and sporulation. The spo0A promoter containing four Spo0A~P binding sites (0A box) is transcribed by two distinct promoters, a σA-recognized promoter Pv during growth, and a σH-recognized promoter Ps during starvation in an autoregulatory fashion. However, how the affinities of Spo0A~P to each of the four 0A boxes affect to switch transcription from Pv to Ps thereby contributing to differentiation is unclear. We show that the relative affinities of Spo0A~P to each of the 0A boxes contribute differential binding of Spo0A~P to each of the 0A boxes causes temporal increase in Spo0A~P, leading to differential cell fate decision. We further show that Pv is sufficient for spo0A expression to promote biofilm formation, but not sporulation, and Ps promoter is sufficient for spo0A expression to promote sporulation, but not biofilm formation. These results reveal that differential binding of Spo0A~P to each of the 0A boxes is one of the key determinants to achieve developmental increase in Spo0A~P, leading to cell fate decision.

(5) We show that Spo0A~P directly binds to three conserved DNA sequences (0A1-3) in the promoter region of the mother cell-specific lytic transglycosylase gene spoIID, which is transcribed by σE-RNA polymerase (RNAP) and negatively controlled by SpoIIID transcription factor. Systematic mutagenesis of the 0A boxes reveals that Spo0A activity is essential for the mother cell-specific event, in which spoIID expression is precisely controlled by the coordination of three factors, Spo0A~P, SpoIIID, and σE-RNAP for proper sporulation. Our finding is in contrast to the current consensus mechanism in which Spo0A activity is required mainly for entry into sporulation.

The project provided training opportunities for multiple graduate and undergraduate students with an emphasis on cross-disciplinary approaches, including synthetic and systems biology, single-cell microscopy, and mathematical modeling. The effective integration of these research methods is becoming increasingly important to address complex biological questions in the post-genomic era. The lab members receiving this training represent the next generation of life scientists, and this project has provided them with tools to continue pushing the boundaries of the research field.
